ler—in contrast to the cilium, which acts more like an oar.”*Both fla-
gella and cilia are intricate structures, and Behe describes the many molecu-
lar parts and systems that have to be present if they are to do their jobs. He
concludes that the complexity of the organization dooms any attempt to ex-
plain its emergence as the result of natural selection. “As biochemists have
begun to examine apparently simple structures like cilia and flagella, they
